children.value: As a reminder, we are already
functions in Python all the time --- we are simply using functions built into the language, such as the

function to return the minimum value from some collection.
Now let’s define a Python function. Let’s make a function that returns the combination of

import numpy as np
def f(x):
    answer = np.sin(x)*np.cos(x)**2 
    return answer
Here we are using the special Python
to define the name of the function (here
), and in parenthesis, we add the
). We end the line in a colon (much like a loop).
“Inside” the function, we indent our code (four spaces or a tab) and then place any computations we want to carry out. Here, we compute
to be the multiplication of our two trig functions.
Finally, we use the reserved word
to “return” this answer from the inside of the function back out into the rest of our code.
This has to do with something called
, which we will get to shortly

Functions are useful for many reasons. To list some obvious ones, they allow a calculation to be encapsulated and the code
. If we need the output of that multiplication many times in our code, we can call
. Now in this case, that’s not so bad --- but we can write functions with many more steps (lines of code).
Beyond that, functions are useful due to their
So far, when we have written scripts in python, we define
directly on lines of the file (or in the interpreter). At any later time, we can
, to get the value of the variable we defined in our function.
You should find that we can’t!
is not defined is because any variable defined
. You can think of it like an automotive assembly line at a factory. Raw materials (the
) enter at one end, the factory uses a set of screws, bolts, etc., to build the car, and the final car is
. We are not concerned with the steps that happened inside the factory, and those variables (like tools) are reused every time the function is called.
More formally, Python defines several levels of
. Scope defines where a variable is allocated and accessible. Variables made in a Python script are in the scope of that module. When you
that script, your interpreter can access any variable you made in the script.
, which is limited just to the function. Variables made there only “exist” inside the function. That said, a function

a = 10 
def f(x):
    return a + x

print(f(10))

to use variables from a larger scope than the function within a function. Think about it: Functions are beneficial because they are self-contained units of callable code. We should be able to, for example, copy and paste our function into a different file and use it there. If the function relies explictly on variables outside the function, we can’t do this.
So far, we’ve defined our functions minimally. But there are two steps we can take to make our functions better
. Documentation is extremely important in code; we’ve covered comments, and this is the next step for making clear the behavior of our code. Let’s start with a new, slightly more complex function:
kepler_period(1) #should give earth's year in days!
Technically, this function is already more documented than our previous functions, because its
are clearer in defining what they should be. But we can do more. First, we will
We add a colon to each argument and specify the
), and at the end, we use an arrow (->) to indicate the return type of the function, before the final colon.
on execution that your inputs to functions match their type annotations. But external packages (like

We’ll return to deeper questions about type annotations later (e.g., what if multiple types are acceptable?)
--- this is a specialized string within our function which can be used to verbose-ly define its arguments and returns.

def kepler_period(sma_au:float)->float: 
    """
    Returns the orbital period (in days) for solar system bodies given their semimajor axis length (in AU).

    Parameters
    ----------
    sma_au: float
        body's semimajor axis (sma) in AU units 
    
    Returns
    -------
    period: float
        the orbital period (in days). 
    """
    return np.sqrt(distance_au**3/7.496e-6)

The docstring, defined with triple quotes (which allows multiline strings) now gives a sentence-long description of the function, defines the arguments and returns, and their data types, as well as notating optional arguments and indicating their default values. For a one line function, this is a bit overkill, but for functions you write for your research, it can be very useful to have good documentation. We can see the documentation for

data.name: stdout
data.text:
Help on _ArrayFunctionDispatcher in module numpy:

argmax(a, axis=None, out=None, *, keepdims=<no value>)
    Returns the indices of the maximum values along an axis.
    
    Parameters
    ----------
    a : array_like
        Input array.
    axis : int, optional
        By default, the index is into the flattened array, otherwise
        along the specified axis.
    out : array, optional
        If provided, the result will be inserted into this array. It should
        be of the appropriate shape and dtype.
    keepdims : bool, optional
        If this is set to True, the axes which are reduced are left
        in the result as dimensions with size one. With this option,
        the result will broadcast correctly against the array.
    
        .. versionadded:: 1.22.0
    
    Returns
    -------
    index_array : ndarray of ints
        Array of indices into the array. It has the same shape as `a.shape`
        with the dimension along `axis` removed. If `keepdims` is set to True,
        then the size of `axis` will be 1 with the resulting array having same
        shape as `a.shape`.
    
    See Also
    --------
    ndarray.argmax, argmin
    amax : The maximum value along a given axis.
    unravel_index : Convert a flat index into an index tuple.
    take_along_axis : Apply ``np.expand_dims(index_array, axis)``
                      from argmax to an array as if by calling max.
    
    Notes
    -----
    In case of multiple occurrences of the maximum values, the indices
    corresponding to the first occurrence are returned.
    
    Examples
    --------
    >>> a = np.arange(6).reshape(2,3) + 10
    >>> a
    array([[10, 11, 12],
           [13, 14, 15]])
    >>> np.argmax(a)
    5
    >>> np.argmax(a, axis=0)
    array([1, 1, 1])
    >>> np.argmax(a, axis=1)
    array([2, 2])
    
    Indexes of the maximal elements of a N-dimensional array:
    
    >>> ind = np.unravel_index(np.argmax(a, axis=None), a.shape)
    >>> ind
    (1, 2)
    >>> a[ind]
    15
    
    >>> b = np.arange(6)
    >>> b[1] = 5
    >>> b
    array([0, 5, 2, 3, 4, 5])
    >>> np.argmax(b)  # Only the first occurrence is returned.
    1
    
    >>> x = np.array([[4,2,3], [1,0,3]])
    >>> index_array = np.argmax(x, axis=-1)
    >>> # Same as np.amax(x, axis=-1, keepdims=True)
    >>> np.take_along_axis(x, np.expand_dims(index_array, axis=-1), axis=-1)
    array([[4],
           [3]])
    >>> # Same as np.amax(x, axis=-1)
    >>> np.take_along_axis(x, np.expand_dims(index_array, axis=-1), axis=-1).squeeze(axis=-1)
    array([4, 3])
    
    Setting `keepdims` to `True`,
    
    >>> x = np.arange(24).reshape((2, 3, 4))
    >>> res = np.argmax(x, axis=1, keepdims=True)
    >>> res.shape
    (2, 1, 4)

children.value:
def kepler_period(sma_au:float,
                  star_mass: float = 1.989e+30,
                  G: float = 6.674e-11)->float: 
    """
    Returns the orbital period (in days) for solar system bodies given their semimajor axis length (in AU).

    Parameters
    ----------
    sma_au: float
        body's semimajor axis (sma) in AU units 
    star_mass: float, optional
        mass of the stellar (dominating) body, in kg, default 1.989e30 (sun's mass)
    G: float, optional
        gravitational constant in SI units, default 6.674e-11
    Returns
    -------
    period: float
        the orbital period (in days). 
    """
    sma_meters = 1.496e+11 * sma_au 
    P_squared = (4*np.pi**2*sma_meters**3)/(G*star_mass)
    return np.sqrt(P_squared)*1.15741e-5
Let’s test that our function can still work with
provided (and of course that it is still correct!)

With a bit of extra unit massaging (putting everything in SI units, then converting the end result from seconds to days), we see we get earth’s period out accurately. However, if we wished, we could now start playing with solar system parameters:

children.html: 5×1030  kg5\times10^{30}\; \rm kg5×1030kg
2×1030  kg2\times10^{30}\; \rm kg2×1030kg

Notice that because
is a non-positional argument, we had to give its name explicitly when adding it in. This is why optional arguments are also called
arguments --- we can give some, none, or all, and in any order (after the positional arguments).
When defining a function that has both
(required) and optional arguments, the positional arguments must come first, Thus,
As a (quick) preview of what is to come, here’s that same function again, but I’ll allow the
package to handle all the unit conversions for us:

import astropy.units as u 
import astropy.constants as ac
def kepler_period(sma:u.Quantity,
                  star_mass: u.Quantity = 1*u.Msun,
                  G: u.Quantity = ac.G)->u.Quantity: 
    """
    Returns the orbital period (in days) for solar system bodies given their semimajor axis length in any length units.

    Parameters
    ----------
    sma: u.Quantity
        body's semimajor axis (sma) in any length units
    star_mass: u.Quantity, optional
        mass of the stellar (dominating) body, in any mass units
    G: u.Quantity, optional
        gravitational constant in any appropriate units.
    Returns
    -------
    period: u.Quantity
        the orbital period (in days). 
    """
    P_squared = (4*np.pi**2*sma**3)/(G*star_mass)
    return np.sqrt(P_squared).to(u.day)
Extra arguments and keyword arguments, Packing, and Unpacking

children.label: Extra arguments and keyword arguments, Packing, and Unpacking

children.value:
In some cases, it is useful to define a function which takes in an arbitrary set of arguments.
For example, if the output of a previous function produces an unknown number of items, we may wish to admit all of them to the next function we call.
We will handle this using a Python technique known as

).
This is a special operation that allows iterables (e.g.
) to be created from function argument lists, or to be turned

is a single list.
Under the hood, the asterisk in the function call tells Python to
the list and feed each value as a separate argument to the function, in order.
We can play a similar game with
--- here, we will need a double-asterisk:
in the function call gets translated to
, as we would normally provide the function.

These are examples of unpacking a single object into parts to feed into a function. What about the reverse?
Let’s start with an example:

def dist_from_parallax(*args):
    """Simple function to return distance (pc) from a parallax (in ''). 
    Takes any number of input parallaxes and returns a list of distances.
    """
    return_list = []
    for parallax in args:
        return_list.append(1/parallax)
    return return_list
When we use the asterisk operator in the

of a functions arguments, we do the reverse of the unpacking above.
Here, we take any inputs to the function (an arbitrary number of inputs), and
them into a list we are calling
is available inside the function, where we loop over it to calculate distances from the inputs (assuming they are parallaxes).
In practice, it would probably better to write this function to expect a single iterable (
), and to do the calculation in a vectorized way.
We can play the same game with keyword arguments (i.e.,

) into a dictionary accessible in the function.
Here I’ll use an example more typical --- adding
to a function that already has some arguments.
Here, I’ve made what a coder would call a
. This function’s goal is to get the periods for a list of input semimajor axes (i.e., feed in the sma for Mercury, Venus, Earth,...), then spit out a list with all the periods.
function needs that one input (here, fed in from the loop as
take extra parameters for the star mass and gravitational constant. Instead of making those
arguments of our wrapper, we can use
to tell it to take any extra arguments and make a dictionary out of them.
Inside our function, there is now a variable called
do stuff with it here, if we desired. But I simply pass it into our internal call to
that dictionary back into functional arguments.
Can you see a way this could currently go wrong? There is a circumstance when passing kwargs to our wrapper that will generate an error.
does not accept arbitrary kwargs, if we ran

We could stay safe from this by adding
, then any proper (defined) kwargs would be caught, and extra ones would get shoved into a dictionary that could be safely ignored.
allow us to encapsulate short (ish), general tasks into a clean, easy to debug framework
